doc.field: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Collection of Video Recordings
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives Collection of Video Recordings

The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University, a special collection documenting the history of United States radicalism, labor, and progressive social action, accumulated this artificial collection of video recordings gradually over the years through purchases, donations, or separations from manuscript collections or organizational records in the library's holdings. The recordings document a wide range subjects concerning the history of the labor movement and leftist or progressive organizations.

The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University, a special collection documenting the history of United States radicalism, labor, and progressive social action, accumulated this artificial collection of video recordings gradually over the years through purchases, donations, or separations from manuscript collections or organizational records in the library's holdings. The recordings document a wide range subjects concerning the history of the labor movement and leftist or progressive organizations.

This collection consists of video recordings collected by the Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wanger Labor Archives, or separated from manuscript collections or organizational records in the library's holdings. The recordings document a wide range subjects concerning the history of the labor movement and leftist or progressive organizations.

The Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives at New York University, a special collection documenting the history of United States radicalism, labor, and progressive social action, accumulated this artificial collection of video recordings gradually over the years through purchases, donations, and separations from manuscript collections or organizational records in the library's holdings.

There is no documentation concerning the provenance of several items in this collection. In August of 2016, Robert Cohen donated a videocassette of a lecture by Howard Zinn; the accession number associated with this gift is 2016.037.

Researchers interested in using audiovisual materials in this collection (films, cassette tapes, VHS tapes, et cetera) must use a digitized copy, which we refer to as an access copy. Researchers may view an item's original container, but the media themselves are not available for playback because of preservation concerns. Materials that have already been digitized are noted in the collection's finding aid and can be requested in our reading room; materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. These requests are free of charge and can be made in anticipation of your visit. The process typically takes four to six weeks. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A librarian will respond to you with further information.
